We obtained the result for the classical theory.
In quantum  scale invariant theories, when the anomalies upon the transformation \eqref{glWtrans} are absent or cancel each other, our mechanism still may bring emergent 
effective low energy scales.\footnote{Surely in the quantum case one has to deal with an effective quantum potential
and the mean fields rather than with classical fields.} Therefore our result can be seen as the  first
step towards the construction of truly\footnote{i.e. both at classical and quantum levels} scale invariant  extensions of the Standard Model.

This is not the only example of  appearance of scales in truly scale invariant models: it is well known that each
solution of the Einstein equations solves also the Bach equations, which come out from the scale invariant Weyl action. 
This property allows to think of the Einsteinian gravity without the Einstein-Hilbert action  \cite{Maldacena}.  
In such an approach the scales (e.g. the gravitational and the cosmological constants) enter in the theory via proper conditions for the fourth order differential equations of motion.

It is also interesting to study effects of rippling gravitational backgrounds in quantum theories beyond the scope
of  scale invariant generalizations of the Standard Model.
Note that in our classical consideration the rippling gravitational background affects just  the
mass parameter\footnote{at the leading order in $\omega$ i.e. at low energies } but not the quartic coupling constant $\lambda$, i.e.  the only dimensionful parameter in the action
\eqref{Sint}.
 It is known that the observed Higgs mass
at $125$ GeV \cite{Aad:2012tfa,Chatrchyan:2012xdj} is compatible with the Standard Model if the running quartic coupling constant $\lambda(s)$ becomes
negative at the energy scales $s\sim 10^{10}$ GeV, thereby creating the vacuum instability problem \cite{EliasMiro:2011aa, Bezrukov:2012sa}.
Non triviality of the beta function of the quartic coupling of the Standard Model   
 may lead to a bigger influence of  rippling  gravitational backgrounds on the quadric vertex of the Higgs potential.
It would be very interesting to figure out whether (and how) it really
affects the vacuum stability, but this is beyond the scope of the present paper.
